about_the_game:
You are no one.

In the police city-state of Annexia, where moral decay festers beneath the boot of the authoritarian Ziggurat organisation, you are no one. Tasked with assuming the identity of Albert Buchannan, a fading writer embedded deep within the city's underworld, you slip into his life of narcotics and paranoid delusions. But as the days pass, the lines between you and Buchannan blur. His addictions become yours. His past bleeds into your present. And the longer you live as him, the further you drift from whatever you once were.

Yet your employers demand results. They are desperate for information on Sister Blue, a name that echoes through the city like a ghost - unseen, ungraspable, yet seemingly at the heart of everything. To uncover the truth, you must trade in illicit substances, switch identities, and navigate the warring factions vying for control of Annexia’s decaying heart. Talk to its many inhabitants, forge uneasy alliances, and betray those who trust you - all while evading the ever-present Ziggurat agents watching from the shadows.

Key Features:

  • A narcotics trade simulator – collect, buy, sell, and use a wide array of substances to survive and manipulate the city's power struggles.

  • A fractured identity – live as Albert Buchannan, but for how long? Assume new identities to uncover multiple layers of the story.

  • A web of conspiracies – work with or betray competing organisations, each with their own agendas and secrets.

  • A world full of voices – talk to a vast cast of NPCs to piece together Annexia’s dark history and your own fading past.

  • A game of survival – manage acute alcoholism, evade Ziggurat’s watchful agents, and walk the fine line between madness and truth.

In Annexia, your identity is a currency that slips through your fingers like dust. Will you escape the city with answers, or will you vanish into its endless streets?

content_descriptors.notes: Contains frequent references and depictions of drug use and sales, as well as some course language and some pixelated depictions of blood and violence.
